questions.tweetText: What is the correct definition of a “vamp” in memecoins?

options.label: A sudden pump with no pullback
When the liquidity of a coin is sucked into another coin
A stealth relaunch after a rug

questions.lesson: “Vamp” = liquidity gets siphoned from one coin into another (usually a fresher narrative).

questions.tweetText: What does “PVP” mean in the context of memecoins?

options.label: Pair vs Pair on a DEX
Two coins fighting each other (narrative vs narrative)

questions.lesson: PVP = coin vs coin — two narratives competing for capital and attention.

questions.tweetText: Elon Musk tweets (context image). Which ticker is most likely to reach the highest market cap?
questions.lesson: Short, pronounceable, and clean wordplay (“Down” + “Donald”) tends to travel further and stick better.

questions.tweetText: Elon Musk tweet (context image). Which ticker is most likely to reach the highest market cap?

options.label: POTUS — Pedo Of The United States

questions.lesson: Acronym recognition matters. “POTUS” is immediately familiar and compact — strong branding (content here is descriptive, not endorsement).

questions.tweetText: What is meant by the term “bundle” in memecoins?

options.label: Multiple wallets within one coin controlled by a single individual
A community group-buy via a bot
Liquidity paired with a marketing budget

questions.lesson: A bundle typically refers to several wallets on one coin controlled by one actor.

questions.tweetText: Another key factor is naming (not just the ticker). Musk tweets about a new Grok companion called ANI. Select the correct ticker and name.
questions.lesson: Mind capitalization and phrasing. Consistent style with a clean ticker often converts best.
